ratings.description: Bassinet is our safety assessment of the means of attaching the bassinet to the play yard.
The Ease of use score is based on our judgment of ease of set-up and closure, and accessibility and ease of use of the latches.
Overall score is based on safety assessments, ease of use, and portability.
Portability is based on our judgment of how easy it is to pack and carry or transport the packed play yard.

Safety score incorporates assessments of latching mechanisms; stability; strength and integrity of floor, sides, posts and rails; mattress displacement; entrapment hazards; protrusions, pinch points, and openings,  and spacing requirements.  Scoring also takes into account such items as whether a model has a changing table safety strap, whether the bassinet is easy to dislodge - by an older sibling, for example - and whether the mattress is securely attached and cannot be easily dislodged from the bottom of the play yard by the child occupant.
The weight of the play yard in pounds.

bottomLine: This Baby's Dream single drop gate was Good overall. But there was a safety issue: the drop gate did not latch automatically when the gate was closed.
highs: This Baby's Dream single drop gate was Very Good in its Construction, but just Good overall. It converts to Toddler Bed and Full-size Bed.
lows: Fair in Safety and in Ease of Assembly. Assembly process is complicated, awkward and took longer than many other models tested. Conversion to bed mode(s) requires separately purchased kit or parts.
name: generationNext_153836

ratings.description: Indicates that a crib can convert, with or without additional parts, to a toddler bed (TB), day bed (DB), or full-sized bed (FB).  Some parts or conversion kits are only available separately.
Construction incorporates mattress support integrity,  types of hardware used, sample defects, if any.

Ease of assembly is based primarily on the amount of time required to assemble the crib, clarity, accuracy and explicitness of the instructions, whether or not the correct hardware was included and whether there was easy access to areas where fasteners must be tightened securely.
Overall score is based on safety, construction and ease of use.

Safety for each crib was assessed by our testing, a good portion of which is comprised of applying the ASTM F1169 Consumer Safety Specification for Full-Size Baby Cribs.  This ASTM safety standard was included by the US Consumer Product Safety Commission as part of the mandatory regulatory requirements issued under Section 104 of the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act.

review: This Baby's Dream single drop gate was Good overall, and Very Good in Construction. But the drop gate latches did not relatch automatically when closed, and a possible pinch point were safety concerns. Ease of Assembly was only Fair. Assembling this crib was more complicated and took longer than many other models tested. There were a lot of parts, and assembly was awkward. Not all the steps have illustrations.

review: This Westwood Design stationary side was Good overall. It was Good in Safety. Its Construction was Very Good with one exception; when attaching the sides to the head- or footboards, the side top rails are just a bit longer than they should be (or the bolts are too short); this should be an easy fix for the manufacturer. Ease of Assembly was Very Good in that the steps were straightforward, but a second person is required to hold the headboard while the first tightens the hardware.

lows: Even though its price made it a candidate for CR Best Buy status, we did not give the Sundvik crib that designation for one reason: Ikea recommends that "for the safety of your child," you buy an Ikea crib mattress. The only difference between Ikea's and a standard crib mattress is that Ikea's is a few fractions of an inch longer and wider. Online reviews of Ikea cribs occasionally mention that there are gaps between the sides and a standard mattress. Although the Sundvik crib itself falls within the federal specifications for inside dimensions, it, too, is slightly on the large side in those dimensions. It seems self-serving for Ikea to make both their crib and mattress slightly larger than average, but it also creates a safety concern. If a parent should buy a non-Ikea mattress that happens to be on the low side of the federal size specifications, there could be hazardous gaps.

A rating of how easy it is to securely and correctly install each seat using the LATCH system in a variety of vehicles and how well the seats fit each vehicle once installed.

summary: Currently, along with the B-Safe, one of two infant seats offered by Britax. On October 29, 2010, Britax Child Safety, Inc. announced a recall of some models of the Britax Chaperone Infant Car Seat. Read more about the Britax recall. On January 30, 2012, Britax recalled certain Chaperone infant child seats produced from September 1, 2010, through April 30, 2011, because the harness adjuster can detach from the seat shell, increasing the risk of injury or death to the child in the event of a crash. Read the full recall notice.

bottomLine: A good performer, but limited in use by instructions that don't allow belt installation in vehicles with seatbelts anchored more than 2" forward of seatback.

summary: The Via I470 is the only infant seat currently offered under The First Years brand. Similar to the Lamaze Via I470 offered at some retailers.

bottomLine: A balanced seat that includes features that make LATCH installation and adjustments for different sized children easier. A better choice if you're installing with LATCH than with the vehicle belts. Seat is nearly identical to Evenflo's Serenade in appearance and function, but includes Evenflo's e3 triple layer foam intended to provide better side impact protection. Installs well in many vehicles without the base, making it a good alternative for those that live in the city and use a taxi often or don't use the seat base.

summary: The only infant seat currently offered under the Cosco name. Cosco is a division of the Dorel Juvenile Group.

bottomLine: A unique, lightweight design that could prove beneficial in seating positions or vehicles that can accommodate it as it requires a top tether for harnessed installation.
highs:
• A unique, lightweight design that folds into its own carrying case
  • Its requirement for top-tether use can help reduce forward movement
  • Its flat, thin back takes up less forward space
lows:
• Cannot be used in harness mode in vehicles or seating positions that lack a top-tether anchor
  • Fits securely in cars that have sufficient seat back height to support its fabric back
  • Better suited to LATCH rather than belt installation in harnessed mode
  • Though potentially tempting for travel due to its lightweight and portability it is not approved for aircraft use

summary: The only hybrid toddler booster model available, this seat is a unique, lightweight design offered by Safety 1st, a brand under the Dorel Juvenile Group.

bottomLine: With designs like Dale Earnhardt Jr., Dora the Explorer, SponegeBob Squarepants and Batman, this seat may help encourage child restraint and booster use. Although the instructions and labels for this seat are excellent, some of its features are more difficult to adjust and it is one of the more challenging seats in this group to install in a vehicle. Its narrow belt path and lack of access through the cover make getting a secure installation with a vehicle seat belt difficult. Latch installation, although better, also suffers due to the limited ability to tighten the LATCH strap. Pay particular attention when installing as a booster that when your child moves the vehicles seat belt retractor can still automatically re-tighten the seat belt. We found the belt routing in some vehicles has too much friction and prevents the retractors from doing their job.
highs:
• Push-on LATCH connectors
  • Head restraint offers added adjustment in booster mode for taller kids
  • Labels on seat provide excellent guidance for use
lows:
• Can be difficult to tighten the LATCH belt without pulling it through the belt path beneath the cover
  • Difficult to release LATCH tension behind the seat
  • Installation with vehicle seat belts is difficult
  • Awkward to thread shoulder belt into guide in booster mode
  • Some booster installations may prevent the seat belt from taking up seat belt slack when a child moves

summary: The Graco Argos 70, with its 70 lb. harness capacity, is one of Graco's toddler boosters seats with high weight limits. It is similar to the Graco Nautilus 3-in-1.

bottomLine: The Secure Kid DLX, formerly named SecureKid 400, is a reasonably priced straightforward seat that works well in its harnessed mode. This seat shares its basic platform with the Maestro and Chase models of Evenflo seats but each seat model has some different features and weight limits. This model of Secure kid offers premium SureLatch connectors which automatically retract the LATCH belt making installation very easy. The adjustable headrest with built in shoulder guide is a needed improvement over the Maestro and Chase. It does a good job of positioning the shoulder belt on a child sized dummy in our testing. Be careful when switching to booster mode to use the correct belt guide on the headrest. Evenflo left the original belt guide intended for the Maestro / Chase on the seat shell, so technically this seat has two belt guides even though one is beneath the cover.
highs:
• Lighter weight makes it easier to transport
  • Reasonable price
  • Instructions do an excellent job of describing when to transition your child to this seats booster mode
lows:
• Continuous harness loop makes it harder to maintain even tension for the harness on both sides
  • The chest clip can be hard to move
  • Harness Buckle can be stiff to open and close

summary: The SecureKid LX, formerly named SecureKid 300, is one of many toddler booster seats offered by Evenflo. Other models include the Maestro, Chase Select, and SecureKid DLX.

bottomLine: Once we figured out how to use the rigid LATCH system, the TrendZ FastBack 3-in-1 impressed us with excellent installation with LATCH, but that’s where its impressiveness ended. Because of its 28lb physical weight and 22lb minimum child weight this seat, used with its harness, is limited to 15lbs of use with the LATCH system in most vehicles. Coupled with its poor installation with vehicle seat belts most users will find this seats use limited and frustrating at best. Keep in mind the 22lb minimum weight is just that, a minimum. Most child passenger safety groups recommend rear-facing until 2 years old or roughly 28 lbs. Under this situation you basically can't use this seats LATCH system. To make matters worse, the foam side wings and seat back easily break during normal use. As a booster seat the TrendZ FastBack does well although it's weight again becomes a potential issue.
highs:
• Rigid connectors offer easy and very secure LATCH installation
  • High harness (70 lbs.) and booster (120 lbs.) capacity can keep children harnessed longer and offer a good option for heavier kids
  • Can be used as either a highback or backless booster
  • Very good crash protection / belt fit in highback booster mode
lows:
• Installation with vehicle seat belts is poor
  • Vehicle belt path is narrow and difficult to thread belt through
  • Heavy and bulky seat
  • Although LATCH installation is excellent, LATCH use of this seat is very limited due to the weight of the seat
  • Foam side "wings" and seat back break off easily

summary: The TrendZ FastBack 3-in-1 is toddler booster seat manufactured by Baby Trend.

bottomLine: A good performer if it suits your vehicle. Not a seat we recommend for older vehicles that have only lap belts and no top-tether anchor. Britax recommends the tether be used at all times and requires its use with children between 65 and 85 lbs when using the harness. Although this seat has a good fit-to-vehicle score, achieving that fit can be difficult due to complicated belt routing and multiple belt routing options. LATCH installation is better, but the seat can't be used to the full 85lbs harness capacity if installed with LATCH.
highs:
• Push-on LATCH connectors. High harness (85 lbs.) and booster (120 lbs.) capacity can keep children harnessed longer and offer a good option for heavier kids
  • Head restraint offers added adjustment for taller kids when the seat is used in booster mode
lows:
• High price
  • Multiple belt routing options referred to as the "Short belt path" and "Long belt path" complicate installation
  • The long belt path is difficult to use but may be needed to get a secure installation in some cars
  • The short belt path, although easier, may not provide a secure installation.
  • Not a good choice for older cars that have lap belts only and no top tether
  • When used as a booster, the wide belt guides may not position the shoulder belt in an optimal position

summary: The Frontier 85 is one of many toddler booster seats offered by Britax. A similar model called the Frontier 85 SICT includes side impact-protection.

bottomLine: Though not laden with features, the Maestro is a reasonably priced straightforward seat that works well in its harnessed mode. When switching to booster mode be sure to pay close attention to see if the belt fits your child correctly. We found this seat did a poor job of positioning the vehicle seat belt on a child sized dummy in our tests. Evenflo Maestro seats that were built between 11/24/2009 and 4/9/2010 in the U.S.and between 12/17/2009 and 4/26/2010 in Canada have been recalled. The recall involves seats with a model number that begins with “310.”  Maestro child restraints built after April 2010 are not affected by this action.
highs:
• Lighter weight makes it easier to transport
  • Reasonable price
  • Instructions do an excellent job of describing when to transition your child to this seats booster mode
lows:
• Continuous harness loop makes it harder to maintain even tension for the harness on both sides
  • The chest clip can be hard to move
  • The booster belt guide does a poor job positioning the seat belt correctly on a childs shoulder

summary: The Maestro is one of many toddler booster seats offered by Evenflo. Other models include the Chase Select, SecureKid LX, and SecureKid DLX.

bottomLine: Being reminiscent of the old "Shielded" car seat designs the Kiddy World Plus raises many questions within the child passenger safety community. Most of the problems that plagued the old shielded car seat designs such as non-padded trays and a loose fitting shields have been eliminated with this design. Kids may find the snug shield a bit claustrophobic and it places the arms in a somewhat unnatural position.  Without a crotch strap some children may be able to slide out under the shield.
highs:
• Good crash protection scores whether used with the harness or as a booster
  • Good labels and instructions
lows:
• Tether adjuster is difficult to tighten and release
  • LATCH buckle and seat belt buckle must both be bucked and unbuckled every time when putting a child in the seat and installing with a vehicle seat belt
  • Shield limits where children can rest their arms to an unnatural position
  • Cloth cover on shield where children will constantly touch is not removable for washing

summary: The Kiddy World Plus is a US certified version of a European designed seat. This non-harnessed toddler booster seat is reminiscent of the old "Shielded" car seat designs.

bottomLine: A reasonably priced seat that performs well if you can get a secure installation. We found the best way to achieve a secure fit was to fold back the cover of the seat to access the belt path behind where your child will sit. Pulling the belt from this location gives you a better angle to tighten the belt and makes the seat easier to secure. When switching to booster mode be sure to pay close attention to see if the belt fits your child correctly. We found this seat only did a fair job of positioning the vehicle seat belt on a child sized dummy in our tests.
highs:
• Lighter weight seat makes it easier to transport
  • Reasonable price
lows:
• Difficult to get secure with seatbelt installation in some cars that have belts mounted forward of the seat back
  • Narrow belt path
  • Harness adjusts without rethreading but requires uninstalling the seat to change harness position
  • May require pulling LATCH strap into belt path to secure

bottomLine: A reasonably priced seat that performs well if you can get a secure installation. It can be a chore to achieve a secure installation with the vehicle belt and also with LATCH. summary: One of Dorel Juvenile Groups many toddler booster seats offered under the Safety 1st name. In February 2011, some models of Safety 1st Vantage toddler booster car seats, as well as other car seat types and models manufactured between May 1, 2008 and April 30, 2009, were recalled by Dorel Juvenile Group and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, due to a potential for the harness adjustment strap to loosen during use. Learn more in Dorel and NHTSA recall notices.

bottomLine: Though not laden with features, the Chase Select is a reasonably priced straightforward seat that works well in its harnessed mode. This seat shares its basic platform with the Maestro and SecureKid models of Evenflo seats but each seat has some different features and/or weight limits. When switching to booster mode be sure to pay close attention to see if the belt fits your child correctly. We found this seat did a poor job of positioning the vehicle seat belt on a child sized dummy in our tests.
highs:
• Lighter weight makes it easier to transport
  • Reasonable price
  • Instructions do an excellent job of describing when to transition your child to this seats booster mode
lows:
• Continuous harness loop makes it harder to maintain even tension for the harness on both sides
  • The chest clip can be hard to move
  • The booster belt guide does a poor job positioning the seat belt correctly on a childs shoulder
  • Harness Buckle can be stiff to open and close

summary: The Chase Select is one of many toddler booster seats offered by Evenflo. Other models include the Maestro, SecureKid LX, and SecureKid DLX.

bottomLine: Though not laden with features, the Highback is a reasonably priced straightforward seat that works well in both harnessed and booster modes. What this seat lacks in features it makes up for in its simple design and straight forward use. Although the Cosco Highback meets required federal motor vehicle safety standards and there have been no reports of injury or death, Consumer Reports recommends parents who are using a Cosco Highback child car seat manufactured earlier than May 18, 2011, should consider replacing it, based on evidence from our tests that showed some older units can crack in simulated frontal-impact crash tests allowing the harness to loosen.
highs:
• Good crash protection scores whether used with the harness or as a booster
  • Lighter weight makes this seat easier to transport
  • Reasonable price
  • Very good belt fit in booster mode
lows: • Continuous harness loop makes it hard to maintain even tension for the harness on both sides

bottomLine: A basic backless booster.
highs: Very lightweight and easy to transport.

summary: One of multiple boosters offered by Harmony Juvenile Products.

bottomLine: A lightweight seat but its different belt routing may lead to user error.
highs: A minimum weight limit of 40 lbs. encourages parents not to transition children from a harnessed seat to a booster too early. Very lightweight seat.
lows: Lacks the lateral protection, improved belt placement, and more comfortable place for a child to rest his head that the side wings and belt guides of a highback booster provide. Shoulder belt must be routed over the armrest on one side which is different than most other boosters and may be cause for error. The lap belt path places the belt more forward on the child's legs, which may allow additional forward movement in a crash.

summary: One of multiple boosters offered by The First Years / Compass.

bottomLine: This seat is large and heavy, but has benefits for larger kids (both rear and forward facing), for cars that don't have lap and shoulder (3-point) belts or top tethers, and for travel. But it suits these special cases better than it does everyday use. It is often used when parents need three car seats to fit across a vehicle rear seat, due to its narrow shape.
highs: Harness capacity up to 45 lbs. rear facing and 80 lb. forward-facing - the highest available. A good alternative to a booster seat for vehicles equipped with only lap belts. Narrow width may allow three car seats to fit across in some vehicle back seats. Designed to fold for travel.
lows: Pricey, heavy and long seat. Very difficult to securely install rear-facing and lacks recline indicator. Requires separate rear-facing platform (included) to be attached to the seat to achieve correct recline.
name: radianXtSl_159097

ratings.description: A rating of the potential for each seat to limit injury and movement of a child in a crash based on simulated frontal crash tests using child sized dummies.

Our judgment of how easy each seat is to use including the clarity of labels and instructions, adjustments of clips and buckles, the transition of the seat from rear facing to forward facing and installation features such as LATCH connections and top tethers.

A rating of how easy it is to securely and correctly install each seat using both the vehicle belts and LATCH in a variety of vehicles in a forward-facing orientation and how well they fit each vehicle once installed.
Overall score is based on crash protection, ease of use, and fit to vehicle, using LATCH and lap/shoulder belts.

A rating of how easy it is to securely and correctly install each seat using both the vehicle belts and LATCH in a variety of vehicles in a rear-facing orientation and how well they fit each vehicle once installed.

bottomLine: A seat that works better with LATCH installation than vehicle belt, as instructions require most belt installations be done with a belt locking clip though Evenflo is working to eliminate that requirement. One of the better choices if you decide to use a convertible seat for a newborn.

lows: Takes some rocking of the seat and a firm pull to get LATCH strap tight when rear-facing. Belt locking clip required for most vehicle belt installations.

summary: One of the group of "next generation" convertible models from Britax the Boulevard 70 CS includes a number of good ease-of-use features. .

bottomLine: This pricey seat doesn't have as many ease-of-use features as some comparably priced models. Can't be used for newborns. Seat also loses its greatest benefit--the hub--when you transition it to forward-facing.
highs: Hub system and 'strong arm' feature work well for getting a secure LATCH installation. Swivel feature makes it easier to place baby in seat from side.
lows: Doesn't offer a full compliment of ease-of-use features for the price. Hub system can't be used forward-facing, and seat requires installation of separate braces for forward-facing installation. Very difficult to use rear-facing lockoffs for seatbelt installation with the belt in tension. Not for use by newborns (15 lb. weight minimum). Rear-facing level indicator located on hub is not visible when seat is in place.

lows: Long shell may not fit in smaller cars or third rows when rear facing. Confusing harness height adjustment.

bottomLine: A seat that works better with LATCH installation than vehicle belt, as instructions require most belt installations be done with a belt locking clip though Evenflo is working to eliminate that requirement. One of the better choices if you decide to use a convertible seat for a newborn.

lows: Takes some rocking of the seat and a firm pull to get LATCH strap tight when rear-facing. Belt locking clip required for most vehicle belt installations.

summary: The newest among All-in-One models, and the only All-in-One offered by Graco.

bottomLine: This seat is large and heavy, but has benefits for larger kids (both rear and forward facing), for cars that don't have lap and shoulder (3-point) belts or top tethers, and for travel. But it suits these special cases better than it does everyday use. When used in booster mode, the fact that this seat's shoulder belt guide allows the shoulder belt to lay slack when a child moves also makes it a poor choice for use in booster mode. It is often used when parents need three car seats to fit across a vehicle rear seat, due to its narrow width.
highs:
• Harness capacity up to 45 lbs. rear facing, 80 lb. forward-facing and 120 lb. in booster mode make this is a seat that can accomodate larger kids
  • A good alternative to a booster seat for vehicles equipped with only lap belts
  • Narrow width may allow three car seats to fit across in some vehicle back seats
  • Designed to fold for travel.
lows:
• Price
  • Heavy and long seat
  • Very difficult to securely install rear-facing and lacks recline indicator
  • Long back may not fit in smaller vehicles well
  • Requires separate rear-facing platform (included) to be attached to the seat to achieve correct recline
  • The shoulder belt guide used in booster mode is awkward to use and causes the belt to fold and bind within it causing the should belt to lay slack, a safety concern.

summary: Diono is the new name for what was previously Sunshine Kids child seats that now incorporate a booster mode making them all-in-one seats. The RXT is desigend to accommodate larger kids with its 80 lb. harness capacity. The Radian RXT is similar to the Radian GTX.

bottomLine: This seat is large and heavy, but has benefits for larger kids (both rear and forward facing), for cars that don't have lap and shoulder (3-point) belts or top tethers, and for travel. But it suits these special cases better than it does everyday use. It is often used when parents need three car seats to fit across a vehicle rear seat, due to its narrow shape. Provides good belt fit in booster mode.
highs:
• Harness capacity up to 45 lbs. rear facing, 80 lb. forward-facing and 120 lbs. in booster mode make this a seat that can accomodate larger kids
  • A good alternative to a booster seat for vehicles equipped with only lap belts
  • Narrow width may allow three car seats to fit across in some vehicle back seats
  • Designed to fold for travel.
lows:
• Price
  • Heavy and long seat
  • Very difficult to securely install rear-facing and lacks recline indicator
  • Requires separate rear-facing platform (included) to be attached to the seat to achieve correct recline

summary: Diono is the new name for what was previously Sunshine Kids child seats that now incorporate a booster mode making them all-in-one seats.

bottomLine: A seat that requires a critical evaluation of fit before you choose it as it is difficult to install rear-facing and may not fit many vehicles well. Best used as a harnessed seat as it does not provide good belt positioning in booster mode.
highs:
• Reasonable price
  • Harness can be adjusted without rethreading or removing seat
lows:
• Difficult to fit rear-facing in many cars
  • Requires significant bolstering (with rolled towel, for example) to get correct rear-facing recline
  • Wide base may not fit well between seatbelt anchors in some vehicles
  • Provides poor shoulder and lap belt placement in booster mode
  • Lacks storage location for harness when it is removed for booster use
  • One of only two seats (along with the Safety 1st Alpha Omega Elite) that receives a "not recommended" rating by the IIHS for booster fit.

summary: The only all-in-one model offered by Evenflo. Other versions include the Symphony 65 e3 with added side impact protection features and the TruTether version that includes an indicator to show when the top tether is tight.

bottomLine: This Baby Jogger double side-by-side is sturdy, but bulky. Lifting and carrying (as if into a car trunk) was especially awkward. Not car seat compatible. Not for infants under age 6 months.
highs: Stroller feels notably sturdy, according to trained panel. Has a convenient one-touch hand brake located on the side near the handle. Large basket. Other storage, such as pockets, in addition to basket.
lows: Heavier than most. Large when folded. Lacks a folding lock, making it difficult to pick up or move the folded stroller. Lacks parent tray/storage. Both seats of double stroller lack child tray. Baskets are hard to access with seatbacks reclined.
name: cityMiniDouble_194424

ratings.description: Ease of use is based on ease of setting up and using the stroller and all of its features: folding and unfolding, adjusting the safety harness, opening and closing the buckle, engaging and disengaging brakes, lifting and carrying the folded stroller as if placing it into a car trunk, and, for compatible strollers, installing and removing an infant car seat.

Maneuverability is the ease of pushing and maneuvering the stroller with a 40-lb. child on a variety of surfaces including pavement, dirt and grass, through a series of cones, up and down a curb, on straight paths, up- and downhill and around corners.
This is based mainly on ease of use, ease of pushing and maneuvering, and safety.  The displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
Safety for each stroller was assessed by our testing, based on the specifications of ASTM F833-13--a voluntary industry standard--and stability and usage tests designed by Consumers Union.
The weight of the stroller in pounds.

review: Very Good in Ease of Use. Good in Maneuverability. Good in Safety; lower safety score is due to restraint system not meeting criteria in our tests, which are based on the voluntary safety standard.

specs.description: A five-point harness secures the child's upper body and torso for better safety, in our opinion.  "Five-point" refers to the 2 shoulder straps, a waist strap secured to the seat back on either side of the child's midsection, and a crotch strap.  A three-point harness lacks shoulder straps and secures just the waist and lower torso.
The stroller's handle can be adjusted for height or angle to better suit parents of differing heights.

A stroller that is car-seat compatible lets you mount a car seat directly onto the stroller, and comes with any other items, such as an adaptor bar, that are needed to properly install the car seat.  (If you must buy the adaptor separately, we do not consider that stroller "car-seat compatible" as sold.)
One-touch brakes work quickly for added safety. They're also more convenient than standard brakes.  A few models now have hand-operated parking brakes, arguably even more convenient.
This is convenient in restaurants or other tight spaces. It also makes storing at home easier.

Suitability for babies 6 months and younger means the stroller could include a safety flap at the child's feet so he or she doesn't slip out of a large leg hole, or some other means of containing a child of this age. Even with this added feature, the harness should still be used.

summary: This side-by-side double is notably sturdy, but heavy and bulky. Large storage basket. Not car seat compatible, and not for infants under age 6 months.

bottomLine: This side-by-side Zooper double stroller is large and heavy, like many doubles. We think there are better choices among the side-by-sides we've tested.
highs: Both seats have 5-point harnesses. Both seats convert to carriage mode for an infant, but only 1 of the 2 seats is car seat compatible. Large basket. Other storage, such as pockets, in addition to basket. One-touch or linked brakes (one pedal operates both). Self-stands when folded.
lows: Only 1 of 2 seats is car seat compatible. Lacks any kind of tray. Heavier than most, and large when folded. Harness adjustment more difficult than most. Restraint harness buckles were hard to open for some users. Basket hard to access with seat reclined.

bottomLine: This Contours tandem is large and heavy, but the convertibility appeals to some. Seats can face either way (kids can even face each other, if you like). summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: The sturdy, three-wheeled Graco FastAction Fold Click Connect Jogger was very easy to maneuver, though it was heavier than most in our travel system Ratings. Its air-filled tires offer a smooth ride for a child weighing up to 5o pounds. The 5-point harness is a safety plus, and the parent storage and child snack trays are handy. The stroller stands when folded, making it easy to stow the stroller in a closet. But the Graco FastAction Fold Click Connect Jogger Travel System does not have one-touch brakes. It’s safe to use with an infant car seat for walking, though not for jogging or running. And though the manufacturer says the stroller seat and harness are not suitable for infants 6 months and younger, Consumer Reports medical experts recommend you wait until your child is at least one year old before you take him along as a passenger when you jog or run. We did not evaluate this stroller’s running performance.
displayName: FastAction Fold Click Connect Jogger Travel System
highs: This stroller has many great features, including a notably sturdy feel to testers, but it's heavy. Handle shape is especially comfortable. Very easy to fold; just one step. Stands folded. Great for walking or toting your child on outings, but because of the weight, maybe not the best choice for a series of "in and out of the car" errands. Air-filled tires may give a smoother ride, but add a maintenance chore.
lows: The only real detractor is the weight; it's quite heavy at 31 pounds. It is large when folded. Air-filled tires may give a smoother ride, but add a maintenance chore.

summary: This travel system includes the Graco FastAction Fold Click Connect Jogger stroller and a Graco SnugRide Click Connect 35 infant car seat and base.

bottomLine: If easy stowage is important to you, either for putting the stroller in the trunk or closet, the Graco Modes Click Connect Travel System is easy to fold and stands when folded. It’s also extremely easy to maneuver, and accommodates a child weighing up to 50 pounds. Your baby can face forward or backwards, thanks to a versatile seat that allows you to adjust the angle of the entire seat or just the seat-back. The Graco Modes Click Connect also features a large storage basket and handy parent and child trays, as well as one-touch brakes. The 5-point harness was a safety plus, but the handle was not adjustable.
highs: Suitable for infants 6 months or younger. Car seat compatible. Very easy to fold, and stands folded. Seat can face forward or back, toward parent. Can adjust angle of the entire seat (not just the seat back). One touch brakes. Large storage basket.
lows: Large when folded. The stroller met voluntary standard requirements, but got a relatively low score in CR's braking & stability test, compared to other tested models.

bottomLine: Judged a Don't Buy: Safety Risk due to a harness buckle on the stroller's restraint system that released intermittently on three separate samples in our tests, which are based on the voluntary safety standard for strollers. If you already own this stroller, you can continue using the car seat it includes in your car and on the stroller, since it performed well in our separate car-seat tests and doesn't rely on the stroller's restraint system. This is convenient in restaurants or other tight spaces. It also makes storing at home easier.

Suitability for babies 6 months and younger means the stroller could include a safety flap at the child's feet so he or she doesn't slip out of a large leg hole, or some other means of containing a child of this age. Even with this added feature, the harness should still be used.

summary: Judged a Don't Buy: Safety Risk due to a harness buckle on the stroller's restraint system that released intermittently on three separate samples in our tests, which are based on the voluntary safety standard for strollers. Additionally, the buckle released intermittently on a separate test that's also patterned after the safety standard and simulates a stroller hitting a curb. If you already own this stroller, you can continue using the car seat it includes in your car and on the stroller, since it performed well in our separate car-seat tests and doesn't rely on the stroller's restraint system. But we urge you not to use the stroller on its own.

highs: Has many good features, such as smooth and easy maneuvering. The weight and bulk of the stroller is a drawback, while the air-filled tires can be both a plus and a minus: they may give a smoother ride, but they add a maintenance chore. The Expedition ELX can be used for jogging, but see our cautions in the Summary section.
lows: Bulky and heavy. Folding mechanism on handle was awkward for smaller hands, and needed hand strength to manipulate. The fold latch works almost too well; it is so long, and catches so easily, that it is hard to disengage it when trying to open the stroller, a nuisance. Adjusting seat back recline can be awkward unless you adjust handlebar out of the way. Car seat attachment has multiple steps and is not intuitive.

Weight of stroller with included accessories and stroller seat installed (if removable).

review: Very Good overall. Very Good in Ease, Excellent in Maneuverability. Safety score of Good is due to the fact that, in our tests, we were able to pass a 1-inch probe freely between the stroller's fastened harness and a test cylinder. This means that, for a very slim or small baby, the fit of the harness might be a bit loose.

summary: This travel system includes the Expedition ELX stroller and Flex-Loc infant car seat and base. The stroller can be used for jogging or running, although the manufacturer cautions, "Never jog or run with your newborn in the car seat position. Use for strolling only." CR strongly recommends waiting until your child is at least a year old before you take him along in his stroller for a run. If you are not familiar with bicycle-type wheel attachments and how to properly secure them, consult the manufacturer or a bike shop expert before taking this stroller (or any with a bicycle-type wheel) out with your baby as a passenger.

highs: Some good features, but as many drawbacks. Stroller seat is reversible, so the child can face forward or toward the parent. Angle of entire seat is adjustable (rather than just seatback). Handle is adjustable. One-touch brakes. Storage pocket. Stands folded.
lows: Opening the folded stroller is awkward. It's heavy and bulky, and not easy to "shake out" to open. For folding, must lift two levers and depress a tiny button at same time. Handle shape is quite uncomfortable. Lacks parent tray and child tray. Backrest adjustment is a bit difficult, as you must press buttons on both sides, and there's no set place to put your hands to move seatback forward or back. Multiple steps to attach car seat. Large when folded.

summary: This travel system includes the Fuze stroller and Prodigy infant car seat and base. The stroller has some good features, but drawbacks such as the bulk and weight, and the multiple steps to install a car seat - make this overall not as easy to use as some other models.

highs: This system, although pricey at $1170, can be used from birth to toddlerhood. The frame can be used with either the Infant Car Seat (included, with a vehicle base) or the Toddler Seat. Adjustable handle. One-touch brakes. Child can face forward or toward parent. Angle of entire seat can be adjusted (rather than just the seatback). Storage basket can be removed and used as carryall.
lows: Handles, although very easy to adjust, were not comfortable while pushing the stroller. The sheer weight of the car seat adds to the difficulty of using this travel system. Having to remove either seat (infant car seat or the toddler seat) to fold the stroller is a nuisance, and you then have to move 2 pieces when placing into your car trunk. Small-ish storage "pod" or bag is unique in design and appearance, and is removable. But in order to access the contents while it's on the stroller, the parent must bend down and slide the bag off the track. Heavier than most. Lower safety score is due to restraint (allowing 1" probe to pass around waist) not meeting one or more voluntary standard requirements.

summary: This travel system includes the Orbit Baby G2 Stroller Frame, G2 Infant Car Seat and vehicle base, and Toddler Seat. The latter is a stroller seat only, not a car seat. This travel system has a unique, innovative look, but is not a standout in terms of functionality. Bulky and heavy. Best feature: the swivel capabilities of the seat. Worst feature: heaviness and bulk, which adversely affect portability.

bottomLine: Bulky and heavy, but has a large and accessible basket.  Car seat is very easy to attach.  Folding and unfolding are not the easiest.  Unfolding (opening) the stroller is especially awkward.
highs: 5-point harness; straps are fluid and easy to adjust, although buckle is a bit tight when opening and closing. Car seat compatible.  Attaching the car seat is one step - could not be easier.  Overall, feels comfortable to push and is easy to use. Stands folded.
lows: Large when folded. A bit bulky.  Need good hand strength to operate slide/squeeze folding  mechanism. This folding mechanism, located on handle, limits hand placement.  Handle was a bit low for some users, making the stroller feel heavier to push.  Not as easy to push over uneven terrain. Front swivel wheel(s) does not lock. Canopy is a bit stiff to operate.  Seatback is easier to recline than to restore to upright position.

summary: This Graco travel system comes with a Graco SnugRide 30 infant car seat and base.  It can also be used in carriage mode for infants 6 months and younger.

bottomLine: This travel system is fairly easy to use. The too-short car seat securement straps are the worst feature.  Not only are they too short, but they don't line up with the car seat.  It was very difficult (and impossible for some testers) to attach the strap to the car seat.
highs: Very easy to fold and unfold.  Front swivel wheel locks do not have to be lined up.  Easy to push.  Feels sturdy.  Handles are soft and padded; shape is notably comfortable according to trained panel. Car seat compatible. Stands folded.  Large basket is easy to access from back or sides.
lows: 3-point harness, not 5-point, which we prefer for safety.  The rubber car seat straps on the stroller frame are too short, and do not line up properly with car seat, so they are nearly impossible to attach.  Infant car seat will still fit over the groove on tray, but without the latched straps, it does not feel secure. Lower safety score is due to 3-pt harness. Canopy is a bit stiff when adjusting.  Operating backrest recline needs 2 hands and is a little awkward.  Large when folded.

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: This solid stroller offered a smooth ride on rough and even terrain alike, for children weighing up to 50 pounds. Thanks to its sturdy feel, the Chicco Cortina KeyFit 30 Travel System was even comfortable to push, and its adjustable handle for caregivers of varied heights made it especially easy to use. Other helpful features include one-touch brakes, a snack tray for your child, and a storage tray for you. The Cortina is a little bulky and large, even when folded, but it can stand upright on its own—a plus if you want to stow it in a closet. Its 5-point harness is a plus for safety, but we found the waist-belt portion of the harness harder to adjust than the shoulder straps, and the buckle hard to operate on occasion.
highs: This stroller has a sturdy feel, and a very smooth, easy ride. Has a pop-up enclosure for infants 6 months and under. Adjustable handle is comfortable. Easy to push, even on rougher terrain. Car seat is easy to attach. One-touch brakes. Large storage basket.
lows: Stroller is a little bulky. Waist belt portion of harness was a bit harder to adjust than shoulder straps. Buckle seemed harder to operate on some occasions than on others.

summary: This travel system stroller has a sporty look, with 3-point design and some very easy-to-use features: the one-hand fold system, one-touch brakes, and front double wheel with swivel lock. The stroller comes with Britax B-Safe infant car seat and base.

bottomLine: This single traditional stroller is a top choice and replaces models of the Baby Jogger City Versa that were made between May 15 and August 20, 2012, which were recalled by the Consumer Product Safety Commission over safety issues. Pluses include a seat that can recline to various positions and face forward or back, along with an effective, easy-to-use hand brake instead of the usual foot-operated version. A large storage basket and pocket also offer lots of room for diapers and other essentials. But you'll have to remove the seat to fold the stroller-and neither child nor adult has a tray.
highs: 5-point harness is easy to adjust. Stroller feels notably sturdy. Has a storage pocket in addition to large and easily accessed basket. Adjustable handle. Has an easy-to-use and effective hand-operated brake rather than foot-operated pedals. Seat is reversible, so the child can face forward or toward parent, and has multiple recline positions.
lows: Folding, though it's easy, has multiple steps, one of which is having to remove the seat, a minor nuisance. Lacks parent and child trays, but there is other storage.

summary: The Baby Jogger City Versa that we originally tested was recalled in December 2012, after reports of inadvertent collapse during use. We retested after obtaining a replacement frame, which was the manufacturer's fix for the collapse issue. The City Versa with new frame design did well in our tests and is now a Recommended model. It can accommodate up to 50 lbs. It felt sturdy and comfortable to push. The seat is reversible, so the child can face forward or toward parent, and has multiple recline positions. Handle is adjustable. Parking brake is hand-operated (rather than foot-operated).

bottomLine: This large Safety 1st stroller has some good features, but we recommend a 5-point harness for safety.

bottomLine: This Mutsy Evo has some very good features (such as the restraint system and the backrest), but is heavy and a tad bulky. Its maneuverability, or ease of pushing, is excellent.  Adapter, sold separately, is needed to attach car seat to stroller. Child can face forward or toward parent.
highs: Ease of use was very good; the harness and backrest are high points.  The option to have the seat facing forward or toward the parent is great.  Very easy to push and maneuver.  Adjustable handle for parents of different heights.  Mutsy responded quickly when we contacted them regarding the safety hazard of their grab bar.  The new sample we bought and tested (manufactured in January 2013) has a redesigned grab bar with higher clearance, eliminating the submarining hazard in which an unharnessed child could slip beneath the bar, but his head could not.  The company has also fixed some other minor issues.   An adapter must be purchased separately to use the stroller with an infant car seat.
lows: This is a heavy and bulky stroller, so if you will be constantly taking it in and out of your car trunk, be aware of that.  Somewhat pricey at $400.

bottomLine: This phil&teds stroller is another whose aesthetics are stronger than its functionality, according to our testers.  The manual was hard to follow.  If you buy this model, we strongly suggest checking out the video demo on www.philandteds.com/dot.  In this case, the video is worth a thousand words, showing clearly how to use the features - something on which we feel the manual fell short.
highs: Our testers found the comfortable handlebar, one-touch brakes and easy-to-adjust restraint straps the best features on this model.  5-point harness.  Suitable for infants 6 months and younger.
lows: Heavier and bulkier than most. Folding and opening stroller are difficult. Handle adjustment on our samples tended to stick, though the handle itself is quite comfortable. Restraint buckle was a bit stiff to operate. Adapter, sold separately, is needed to attach a car seat to stroller.  Seatback adjustment was complicated and difficult.  Lacks child tray and parent tray or other storage.  Basket is shallow; one tester likened it to a "shelf" rather than a basket. Instruction manual was extremely hard to follow.

summary: This classic Maclaren umbrella has only a few drawbacks, like the dearth of storage, and poor access to basket with the seat reclined.

bottomLine: This single umbrella-style stroller is compact and easy to fold, with a comfortably shaped handle and generous storage basket. It can also accommodate heavier children weighing up to 40 pounds. On the downside, it lacks parent and child trays, and accessing the basket is a challenge with the seat reclined. Because it's light in weight and has average sized wheels for an umbrella, it did not handle as well as some others on uneven terrain.
highs: Small, compact. Very easy to fold. Comfortable handle shape. Large storage basket. Folded size is small.
lows: Felt heavy (for its small size) to some testers. Does not do as well on uneven terrain. Lacks storage/trays for parent and child. Basket is hard to access with seatback reclined.

summary: This lightweight umbrella stroller from Truly Scrumptious by Heidi Klum can accommodate up to 50 lbs. It has one-touch brakes and a handle for carrying the folded stroller. Its best features are compact size and the restraint system.

bottomLine: This Cybex has some good features, but the lack of basket access and the very difficult brake release detract significantly.
highs: 5-point harness. Individual handles are padded; shape is notably comfortable, according to trained panel. Backrest is easy to adjust. Other storage, such as pockets, in addition to basket. One-touch brakes. Very easy to fold.
lows: On the heavy side for such a compact-looking stroller. Releasing fold latch can be hard if wheels have not been locked before folding. Harness adjustment has a slight learning curve, not helped by inconvenient placement of strap adjustment. Some disliked the split (individual) handles, preferring a single handlebar for better control.  Not the best performer on rough terrain.  Lacks parent tray. Lacks child tray. Brake is extremely hard to release (disengage), to the point where once or twice the stroller slipped forward as the frustrated "parent" worked to release the lever.  Canopy is stiff and difficult to adjust evenly.  Basket is small, and hard to access with seatback reclined. Adapter, sold separately, is needed to attach car seat to stroller.

summary: This Chicco umbrella stroller is "2 strollers in 1" as it can also accept a car seat, unlike most umbrella strollers. It is quite compact, with some good features, and can accommodate up to 40 lbs. But our testers felt that the small, limited-access basket and multi-step infant seat attachment detracted from the better features.

bottomLine: This JJ Cole Monroe umbrella stroller has some very good features.  Biggest drawback is the limited access to basket when seat is reclined.
highs: Relatively lightweight. Compact. Easy and intuitive opening and folding.  Easy to push. 5-point harness. Straps are easy and smooth to adjust.  Buckle is easy to operate.  Car seat compatible with JJ Cole Newport infant car seat.
lows: Handle shape is notably uncomfortable according to trained panel; handles are small and hard plastic. Some found stroller a tad  wobbly on rough areas or when going up or down a curb. Front swivel wheel locks must be lined up to fasten.  Seat is easier to recline than to restore to upright position.  Lacks parent tray. Basket is very hard to access with seatback reclined.  Attaching car seat is a multi-step process.  Aligning the heavier-than-most JJ Cole Newport infant car seat is not easy, but once it is aligned, it snaps in easily.

bottomLine: This Bumbleride Flite's best feature is the excellent, fluid, easy to adjust 5-point harness. The Flite is compatible with several brands of infant car seats; most need adapter (included with stroller).
highs: 5-point harness.  The separate handles (typical of umbrella strollers) limit hand placement, but are nicely padded and comfortable.  Compatible with several brands of infant car seats; most need adapter (included with stroller). Other storage, such as pockets, in addition to basket and/or tray. Small when folded. Handle on side of frame is a nice feature, making it easier to carry the folded stroller.
lows: Not the easiest to fold; slight learning curve, and a good grip is needed to lift the mechanism.  Opening requires awkward motion to shake stroller into open position.  The lock that must be depressed to keep the stroller open is rather tight and requires some force.  Seat is easier to recline than to restore to upright position.  Felt somewhat "wobbly" on rough terrain and going up and down curb. Lacks parent tray. Lacks child tray. Basket is small, and hard to access with seatback reclined.  Car seat attachment is a multi-step, fairly complicated process.

Car-seat compatible strollers allow you to mount a car seat directly onto the stroller. (Some strollers require an adapter bar or brackets, usually included with the stroller.) Car seat compatibility is useful when you're moving a sleeping infant from a car to the stroller.
One-touch brakes work quickly for added safety. They're also more convenient than standard brakes.
This is convenient in restaurants or other tight spaces. It also makes storing at home easier.

Suitability for babies 6 months and younger means the stroller could include a safety flap at the child's feet so he or she doesn't slip out of a large leg hole, or some other means of containing a child of this age. Even with this added feature, the harness should still be used.

summary: This model has some good features, but didn't feel sturdy.

bottomLine:
In March 2011, Consumer Reports designated the Zooper Waltz a DON'T BUY: SAFETY RISK because both the grab bar and snack tray posed a strangulation hazard to an unharnessed child. (See the "Summary" for links to CR's original post on the Don't Buy findings, and to the CPSC recall notice.)

Like many traditional, non-umbrella-style strollers, the Zooper Waltz has a tray and grab bar (you can use either) that attaches above a child's legs. The problem: if a child is placed in the stroller unharnessed (something you should never do), this stroller's tray and grab bar have a gap big enough under them to allow an unharnessed child's torso, but not the child's head, to pass.

summary: In March 2011, Consumer Reports designated the Zooper Waltz a DON'T BUY: SAFETY RISK .  The model was voluntarily recalled by the Consumer Product Safety Commission and the manufacturer.

bottomLine: This light and maneuverable stroller from Stokke is designed with the child's seat higher off the ground than a typical stroller.  Stokke says the Scoot can stand in for a high chair when you're out and about with your baby or toddler, since the Scoot's seat height is suitable for a table.  It can accommodate a child weighing up to 45 lbs.   The seat is reversible.  The handle adjusts to suit adults of different heights while pushing.  One-hand fold system.
highs: Excellent maneuverability & ease of pushing. Smooth ride for baby.  Very Good in ease of use.  Adjustable handle is smooth and soft, comfortable. Child's seat is higher (off the ground) than most. Child can be seated facing forward or toward parent. One-touch brakes. Medium-sized storage basket. Folded size is small. Self-stands when folded.
lows: Safety score is lower due to restraint system issue. Not as good on uneven terrain as on smooth. Handle is wide, but still easy to hold and use. Lacks storage/trays for parent and child. Infant car seat adapter is sold separately.

summary: This light, maneuverable stroller from Stokke is designed with the child's seat higher off the ground than most. Stokke says the Scoot can stand in for a high chair when you're out and about, since the seat height is suitable for a table. It can accommodate up to 45 lbs. The seat is reversible, the handle adjustable for adults of different heights to push. One-hand fold system.

bottomLine: Despite its relative weight and bulk, this smooth, sturdy, easy-to-push single combo stroller is easy to maneuver, even on uneven terrain. It's usable from birth with a specific Peg Perego infant car seat or with the infant enclosure feature, and has a reversible seat that accommodates a child up to 45 pounds. A comfortably-shaped handle, grab bar for your child, one-touch brakes, and large storage basket are other pluses. On the minus side, it's easy to hit the rear bar with you feet when pushing. And there's no tray for parent or child.
highs: Smooth. Sturdy. Easy to push and maneuver; does well on uneven terrain. Adjustable handle is comfortable in shape. One-touch brakes. Child can be seated facing forward or toward parent. Suitable for infants under 6 months. Car-seat compatible. Very large storage basket. Self-stands when folded.
lows: A bit heavy, and thus can be hard to tilt up to go up curb or over obstacles. Feet sometimes hit rear bar while pushing. Lacks trays for parent and child, but has a grab bar. Large when folded.

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: The Moodd has a steep learning curve, but once learned, operation is doable.  Air-filled tires may give smoother ride, but add  maintenance chore.  The hard plastic and metal T-bar may be a hazard for a tantruming child, who could hit his head, but the bar is removable.
highs: 5-point harness. Unfolding is very easy.  Car seat compatible; adapter is included. Having to remove the stroller seat in order to install car seat is a minor nuisance. (Bassinet/carrycot is sold separately for newborn to 6 months old.)  Handle is adjustable. One-touch brakes (one pedal operates both). Seat is reversible, so child can face forward or toward the parent.   Stands folded.
lows: Heavier than most.  Bulky. Like this stroller in general, the folding process has a learning curve, but once you get it, it's not difficult. Restraint straps require threadng to adjust length. Handle shape is squared and notably uncomfortable, according to trained panel. Attaching car seat is a multi-step process that can be tricky and awkward. Lacks parent tray or other storage area. Lacks child tray. Basket is small.  Frame can interfere with access to basket.

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: Heavy and bulky.  There is a learning curve with many features.  A mixed bag of good features and others that are really lacking. We really wish that the manufacturer would make the folding latch red or some other color to make it easier to find. It was incredibly frustrating to try to open the stroller and know there was a folding lock, yet NOT be able to find it (it's inside the frame, not outside or on the handle as most others are, and the color blends into the frame so it's even harder to see).
highs: 5-point harness.  Car seat compatible (adapter is included with stroller).  Bassinet/carrycot is available (sold separately) for newborn to 6 months old. Other storage, such as pockets, in addition to basket and/or tray. One-touch or linked brakes (one pedal operates both). Stands folded.
lows: Handlebar is narrow and slightly squared, but padded.  Handling more difficult on uneven terrain.  Brake is stiff and awkward.  Two users noted that brake engaged on its own while they pushed the stroller over uneven surfaces.  Folding can be difficult when buttons on the handle stick, as they often did for our testers.  The folding latch is extremely well-camouflaged (and very difficult to find, even using the illustrations in the manual).  It's doubly frustrating because you can't open the stroller without disengaging it. Car seat attachment had multiple steps. Lacks parent tray or other storage area. Lacks child tray. Basket is small and accessible only from the back with seat reclined. Lower safety score due to restraint system not meeting one or more voluntary standard requirements.
name: malibu_218051

ratings.description: Ease of use is based primarily on ease of using and adjusting the safety harness, folding and unfolding, adjusting backrest, lifting and carrying, engaging wheel brakes and car seat removal and installation (only for compatible strollers).
The relative size of the stroller.
Maneuverability is assessed by trained staffers on how well the strollers maneuvered S-turns through cones, narrow sections, grass, dirt trails, uphill, downhill and curbs while walking.
Overall score is based primarily on ease of use, maneuverability and safety. The displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
Safety is assessed by testing for compliance with the most current version of the standard, ASTM F833-13, and stability and usage tests designed by Consumers Union.
Weight of stroller with included accessories and stroller seat installed (if removable).

review: Lower safety score due to restraint system not meeting one or more voluntary standard requirements.

specs.description: Color
Five-point harness secures child firmly. Unlike a three-point harness, it secures the upper body.
An adjustable handle can accommodate parents of different heights.

Car-seat compatible strollers allow you to mount a car seat directly onto the stroller. (Some strollers require an adapter bar or brackets, usually included with the stroller.) Car seat compatibility is useful when you're moving a sleeping infant from a car to the stroller.
One-touch brakes work quickly for added safety. They're also more convenient than standard brakes.
This is convenient in restaurants or other tight spaces. It also makes storing at home easier.

Suitability for babies 6 months and younger means the stroller could include a safety flap at the child's feet so he or she doesn't slip out of a large leg hole, or some other means of containing a child of this age. Even with this added feature, the harness should still be used.

summary: The Hauck Malibu is car seat compatible.  Large and heavy.  It has a few good features, while others are neither well-thought-out nor well-executed.

bottomLine: This JJ Cole Broadway stroller has a lot going on.  Its multiple functions are not intuitive to use and can be very complicated, as instructions are not very clear.  Restraint system and brake are the best features.
highs: Car seat compatible; can accept several brands of infant car seats, some of which need adapter (included with stroller). Suitable for infants 6 months and younger. Adjustable handle is padded, and its shape is notably comfortable, according to trained panel. 5-point harness is easy and smooth to adjust; buckle is easy to open & close.  One-touch brakes (one pedal operates both). Child can sit facing forward or toward parent.
lows: Must remove seat to fold stroller, and put it back on when opening.  Both folding and unfolding are multi-step processes.  Lacks a folding lock so can be awkward when, for example, you go to put the folded stroller in a car trunk. While pushing the stroller, testers noted that one sample tended to pull to one side slightly. Setup of the infant "pop-up" enclosure had multiple steps, was not intuitive.  Instructions were not totally clear. Once figured out, the setup was not difficult. Backrest recline is overly complicated - different means to be used for infant (easy tilt for carriage mode) or toddler (strap recline mode).   Lacks parent tray. Lacks child tray. Large when folded.

lows: The stroller frame felt jiggly or even "wobbly" while pushing, to some testers. Hard plastic handles were uncomfortable; some felt they were also too low. bottomLine: This Stokke stroller is pricey at about $1000. It is touted especially for its height-adjustable seat, which allows the child to ride much higher above the ground on city streets than most strollers. That feature also lets you use the stroller as a makeshift high chair, pulling it right up to a restaurant or home dining table. It's a solid design with some good features, but the price is prohibitive to many. It's complicated to use; we still have to rely on the user's manual anytime we need to operate it.

specs.description: Five-point harness secures child firmly. Unlike a three-point harness, it secures the upper body.
Adjustable-height handle accommodates parents of different heights.

A car-seat compatible stroller allows you to mount a car seat directly onto the stroller. It's useful when you're moving a sleeping infant from a car to the stroller. (Some strollers require an adapter bar, sometimes included with the stroller.

Extra storage (in addition to the basket below the seat) like saddlebags or pockets -- the larger the better -- gives parents an additional place to safely stow items. Use it instead of hanging items off the handlebars, which can cause the stroller to tip.
According to the manufacturer, stroller can be safely used for jogging or running, as well as walking.
One-touch brakes work quickly for added safety. They're also a bit more convenient than standard brakes.
This is convenient in restaurants or other tight spaces. It also makes storing at home easier.

Suitability for babies 6 months and younger means the stroller could include a safety flap at the child's feet so he or she doesn't slip out of a large leg hole, or some other means of containing a child of this age. Even with this added feature, the harness should still be used.

Trays for the child can hold a snack, drink, or a toy for baby, or just give him a place to rest his hands. The same features for parents provide a place to put your keys, cell phone, and just free your hands to push. (Don't use with hot beverages.)
Weight of stroller with included accessories and stroller seat installed (if removable).

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: The phil&teds Sport was damaged during our Impact Test, but not in ways that constituted a failure of this portion of the standard. The Impact Test performance requirement section of ASTM standard F833-09, Standard Consumer Safety Performance Specification for Carriages and Strollers, reads: The fold locking/latching mechanism shall not disengage or break, or both, and breakage shall not occur to the frame of the unit. Following the impact test, the frame of the phil&teds Sport was bent so much that the front wheel would no longer turn. A consumer would not be able to just pull the frame back out without possibly weakening the area.
name: sport_106586

ratings.description: Ease of use is based primarily on ease of safety harness use, folding and unfolding, adjusting backrest, lifting and carrying, engaging wheel brakes and car seat removal and installation (only for compatible strollers).
Maneuverability was assessed by trained staffers on how well the strollers maneuvered S-turns through cones, narrow sections, grass, dirt trails, uphill, downhill and curbs while walking.

Off-road maneuverability was assessed by panelists on how the strollers maneuvered, with locked front wheel(s), over a course consisting of uphill and level pavement and rough surfaces, downhill pavement, which also included turns on rough surfaces.
Overall score is based primarily on ease of use, maneuverability and safety. The displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
Safety is assessed by testing for compliance with the most current version of the standard, ASTM F833-11, and stability and braking tests designed by Consumers Union.

summary: This model has been tested by our experts. Consumer Reports has identified a possible safety risk in this strollerand rated it Don't Buy: Safety Risk. Learn more.

bottomLine: The Tike Tech City X3 had an angles of recline that passed the standard, yet came quite close to its 150-degree limit. (A stroller with a backrest that reclines to 150 degrees or more is required to have an Occupant Retention feature, or some way to enclose the foot area, such as a securely fastened flap, so that an infant can''t wiggle down and possibly fall out of the stroller.) We recommend that parents not place an unrestrained infant in these, or any, strollers, as they could easily wiggle down or fall. But parents should always use the restraint system whenever putting a baby or toddler in any stroller.

bottomLine: The InStep Safari was damaged during our Impact Test, but not in ways that constituted a failure of this portion of the standard. The Impact Test performance requirement section of ASTM standard F833-09, Standard Consumer Safety Performance Specification for Carriages and Strollers, reads: The fold locking/latching mechanism shall not disengage or break, or both, and breakage shall not occur to the frame of the unit. Following the test, the InStep Safari''s swivel lock was damaged so that the front wheel would only operate in swivel mode. While this is a minor inconvenience, the opposite scenario would be a bigger inconvenience; if the wheel operated in locked mode only, the maneuverability of the stroller on surfaces such as pavement and indoor flooring would be adversely affected.

name: overlandLimited_112749

ratings.description: Ease of use includes such items as opening and folding the stroller, using the harness, adjusting the backrest, lifting and carrying the folded stroller.

Off-road maneuverability is trained panelists' judgments of ease of pushing, maneuvering and turning while walking on a course that included flat pavement, up- and downhill sections of pavement, and a rough dirt/grass/mulch section with tree roots, fallen branches, and the like.
Overall Score is based on Performance, Off-road maneuverability, Ease of use, Safety and Construction quality.
Performance is panelists' judgments of ease of pushing and maneuvering on varied terrain while running.

Safety is assessed by testing for compliance with the most current version of the standard, ASTM F833-11, and a stability/braking test designed by Consumers Union. Strollers that had relatively lower stability on an inclined plane were downgraded accordingly.

specs.description: Five-point harness secures child firmly. Unlike a three-point harness, it secures the upper body.
the handle can be adjusted for height or angle to better suit parents of differing heights.
Some strollers can accept a car seat. If an adapter or bracket is needed, it must be purchased separately.

Extra storage (in addition to the basket below the seat) like saddlebags or pockets -- the larger the better -- gives parents an additional place to safely stow items. Use it instead of hanging items off the handlebars, which can cause the stroller to tip.
Their size relative  to each other.

The 'hand brake lever' is used to slow or stop the stroller while the parent is walking or running. It's different from the 'parking brakes' which are the usually-foot- pedal-operated brakes used when the parent is parking the stroller (i.e., they don't want it to move). Parking brakes keep the stroller from moving; they stay engaged when they are operated. The hand brake lever must be pressed by the user of the stroller to be engaged; if he/she doesn't keep the lever down, the hand brake will not be engaged.
Maximum weight of child (lbs.) is the manufacturer's specified limit for a child passenger..
One pedal operates both rear brakes.
This is convenient in restaurants or other tight spaces. It also makes storing at home easier.
A tray in front of the child, to provide a place for the child to rest his hands, or put a toy or another item.
A place for parents to put their keys, cell phone, a snack.
Weight (lbs.) is the weight of the stroller with any included accessories (none that must be purchased separately).

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: It was Very Good overall, and panelists rated it Excellent for performance and maneuverability. The InStep Run Around is similar, though it lacks a storage basket. It should perform similarly, too.

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: When we performed the impact test from the American Society for Testing and Materials safety standard for Strollers, the BOB Ironman Sport Utility D'Lux (and BOB Sport Utility) stroller failed. The standard specifies that the impact test be conducted at the stroller's claimed maximum weight capacity--which is 70 pounds for both of these models. (According to growth charts from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a 70-lb. child may be anywhere from a large 7-year-old to a very small 12-year-old.) While this caused this stroller to receive a Fair score for Safety, it should perform well when using it with children in the more typical 40-pound range. Learn more in Detailed Test Results below.
name: ironmanSportUtilityDlux_112748

ratings.description: Ease of use includes such items as opening and folding the stroller, using the harness, adjusting the backrest, lifting and carrying the folded stroller.

Off-road maneuverability is trained panelists' judgments of ease of pushing, maneuvering and turning while walking on a course that included flat pavement, up- and downhill sections of pavement, and a rough dirt/grass/mulch section with tree roots, fallen branches, and the like.
Overall Score is based on Performance, Off-road maneuverability, Ease of use, Safety and Construction quality.
Performance is panelists' judgments of ease of pushing and maneuvering on varied terrain while running.

Safety is assessed by testing for compliance with the most current version of the standard, ASTM F833-11, and a stability/braking test designed by Consumers Union. Strollers that had relatively lower stability on an inclined plane were downgraded accordingly.

review:
When we performed the impact test from the American Society for Testing and Materials safety standard for Strollers, the BOB Ironman Sport Utility D'Lux and BOB Sport Utility Stroller failed. The standard specifies that the impact test be conducted at the stroller's claimed maximum weight capacity--which is 70 pounds for both of these models. (According to growth charts from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a 70-lb. child may be anywhere from a large 7-year-old to a very small 12-year-old--all of whom may be too old, or just unwilling, to ride in a stroller.)

The standard specifies that, when a stroller is put through the impact test, "the fold locking/latching mechanism shall not disengage or break, or both."  But when loaded with a 70-lb. "passenger" in our test labs, the BOB strollers, at times, collapsed completely on impact. At other times, the shock absorber adjustment mechanism, which is also part of the fold mechanism, would partially disengage, slipping from the second setting (the one for a child passenger weighing between 41 and 70 lbs.) to the first setting (for a child passenger weighing up to 40 lbs.). When we tested using a far more typical 40-lb. "passenger," both BOB models passed the impact test.

Because the BOB models failed our impact test at their claimed weight capacities, we lowered their safety and overall scores. However, we feel that the 70-lb. weight limits for the 2 BOB models are simply excessive, and that it's far more likely that the weight of a child riding in any stroller would be closer to 40 lbs. or less.

The Ironman was Excellent in running performance, and both models were Excellent in maneuverability; they would have been higher in our Ratings without the Safety concern at what we believe to be an unrealistically high weight limit.  

We spoke with the manufacturer about our impact test findings. They told us that the models in question passed internal and third-party testing for impact at 70 pounds.  We asked them specifically why there is such a high weight limit for the strollers. They told us that their products are designed for longer duration runs and walks where older children may not be able to keep up and would be in a stroller. In answer to our question, they said there were no reports of injuries or fatalities with their products associated with these issues.
