summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: This audio monitor performed well overall. It has an extra parent unit, which is convenient; parents can listen in on baby from two different locations, or leave one unit by their bed for nighttime use while they carry the other with them in the daytime. However, it lacked some desirable features.
highs: Has a room temperature readout and night light. Both baby and parent units can use non rechargeable batteries.
lows: Parent unit lacks indicators for low battery, out-of-range, and whether it's "linked" or "not linked" to the child's unit. The latter two features provide  a definite indication of the parent and baby units communicating.
name: glowGoDuo08092_146591

ratings.description: Battery Life reflects lab measurements of continuous use of the parent unit with  new alkaline or fully charged rechargeable batteries, with the loudness of each unit set to the same level.
Ease of Use rates the presence and convenience of features of each device. For video models it also includes the picture quality of the monitor.

Interference can vary widely depending on the area in which the home is located and what other electronic devices are within the home or are being used by nearby neighbors. When you buy a monitor, choose one that operates on a different frequency from your cordless phone and other wireless devices around your house.
Overall Score is based mainly on Interference and also on Ease of Use Battery Life and Range.
The distance in a typical home and outdoors that a unit can pick up a uniform signal from the baby's unit.

specs.description: To avoid risk of injury. Babies have been injured and strangled by baby monitor cords placed too close to the crib where the child was able to reach them.  If using a baby unit with a cord, be sure to keep it well out of arm's reach of the baby.
Frequency band is the wavelength at which the unit operates.
This is a light or beep that is a definite indicator that the parent and baby unit are 'linked' or 'not linked' i.e. communicating.
This is a light (or an icon on an LCD display) that lets you know the batteries in your parent unit are running low.
Some models feature lullabies and/or other soothing music that will play for your baby at the push of a button.
Some models have a simple nightlight on the baby's unit.
This is a light or beep that lets you know definitively that you've reached the range limit of the monitor, and won't be able to hear if your child cries.
Rechargeable batteries may save parents money over time, especially those who rely on batteries more than AC power for the receiver(s).

Lights on the monitor turn on when the baby cries; the louder he cries, the more lights light up.  This lets you turn the volume down and still know when the baby is crying, or, if you are in a very noisy room, you'll see the lights and know when baby is awake or crying.

specs.displayName: Talk to baby from parent unit
specs.description: This feature allows the parent to push a button and talk to the baby, alerting him/her that mom or dad is on the way.
Displays the temperature in the baby's room.

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: A recommended audio monitor that scored Excellent in preventing interference  and  has many desirable features. Battery life was short and its range was only Fair, a unit that might be better suited for apartments or smaller homes.
highs: This monitor has many of the desirable features. The unit can be set on vibrate mode to alert a parent who's vacuuming, or in a very noisy room of the baby's activity. The parent unit has rechargeable batteries with a low battery indicator this can save money over disposable batteries. The baby unit has battery option. It has an out of range indicator and whether it's "linked" or "not linked" as a definite indicator of parent and baby units communicating.
lows: Scored only Fair for battery life and range.

summary: This model has been tested by our experts.

bottomLine: The frame is reminiscent of a beach chair. There is a learning curve to folding, but once learned, it's easy. But the side containment panels are a safety concern that outweighs good points.
highs: Easy to fold and unfold. The seat cover is easy to remove and replace. Tray has three adjustment positions.
lows: Received a Fair score for Safety due to the three-point harness and, more importantly, due to tearing and/or releasing of the fabric- and-Velcro tabs that secure part of the fabric sides to the chair. This results in a partially-released side panel; a child could get a leg or arm entrapped in the resulting space. Seat height is not adjustable. There are grooves on the chair's arms that are likely to collect food bits and grime. Tray insert does not cover the entire top of the tray, leaving more room for mess.
name: compactFold_222272

ratings.description: Ease of use is based on trained panelists' assessments of harness adjustment and use, folding and unfolding, removing and replacing the tray and tray insert (if any), adjusting seat back and height where applicable, removing and replacing the seat cover.
Overall score is based primarily on safety and ease of use.

Safety for each high chair was assessed by our testing, which is based on the voluntary safety standard, ASTM F404-10.  Tests include evaluations of the restraint system, stability of the high chair, and static and dynamic load assessments as well as other tests.

review: The tabs that secure the fabric sides to the chair on either side tore off, or their Velcro released, during our testing on each of three samples. Side enclosures are supposed to withstand a certain force as if the child is pushing outward; these fabric tabs tore or released at half that force, or less than half in some cases. The child could get a body part entrapped, or worse.

specs.description: Adjustable seat height/positions indicates whether or not the chair's seat height is adjustable, and, if so, the number of positions available.
Harness type is 5-point, incorporating shoulder as well as waist and crotch straps - which we strongly recommend - or 3-point.

specs.description: The manufacturer's suggested method of cleaning everyday spills and mess.

Reclinable seat/positions indicates whether or not the chair has a reclinable seatback, and if so, how many positions are available.
Weight is the weight of the chair (with tray in place) in pounds.

summary: Basic and compact, a little reminiscent of a beach chair. It is inexpensive, at $55, and has some good features, but some serious safety concerns. Seat height is not adjustable.

bottomLine: This Recommended Graco high chair was excellent in overall performance, and was one of the easiest to use. Seat height is adjustable with 6 positions. Seatback adjusts to 3 positions. Its main drawback is that it does not fold, although it can be partly disassembled ( the bottom portion of the frame can be removed) for storage, according to the manufacturer. According to manufacturer, can be used in 4 modes: as a high chair, an infant feeding booster, a toddler booster, or a youth chair. (We tested it as a high chair, only.) Weight is 28lb. Size: Medium; projected footprint is 630 square inches.
highs: Chair has a fixed snack tray as well as an adjustable main tray and a tray insert. Tray is very easy to attach and adjust. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Seat cover is machine washable, and is easy to remove and put back on. Judged easy to keep clean.
lows: Chair does not fold, and is a bit cumbersome.

summary: This Graco high chair offers "4-in-1" convenience, according to the manufacturer. It can be used as a high chair, infant feeding booster, toddler booster or youth chair.

bottomLine: This lightweight and compact Joovy high chair was very good in overall performance. It has few features, but its easy fold and compact size make it a good candidate for travel, or for bringing to grandma's or to the babysitter's house. Seat height and seat back are not adjustable. Weight: 15lb. Size: Small; projected footprint is 590 square inches.
highs: Relatively compact. Very easy to fold; can be folded with one hand. Has a built-in handle to ease carrying. Can fold with tray in place. Straps of harness are very easy to adjust to fit child. Tray swivels to make seating child easier. Judged easy to keep clean.
lows: Tray has only one horizontal adjustment position; depending on size of child, might be overly tight or overly loose spacing between child's tummy and the tray. Actually removing tray for cleaning is difficult; must pull a tab out and the tray upward. Seat height and seat back are not adjustable. Seat cover is difficult to remove and put back on, and is wipe-clean only (not machine washable).

summary: This Joovy high chair is compact and light in weight, but has relatively few features.

bottomLine: This Safety 1st high chair was very good in overall performance. Seat height is adjustable with 6 positions. Seatback adjusts to 3 positions. Has a fixed snack tray in addition to adjustable main tray and tray insert. Has only a 3-point harness, a safety disadvantage. Weight: 19lb. Size: Large; projected footprint is 791 square inches.
highs: Very easy to fold and unfold. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Has a fixed snack tray in addition to adjustable main tray and insert. Tray is very easy to attach and adjust. Easy to keep clean. Seat cover is machine washable. Seat cover is easy to remove and put back on.
lows: Relatively large; takes up more floor space than most that we tested. Harness belts are secured through slots in seat back and bottom with folded-over, stitched loops of webbing rather than a plastic or metal tab that holds more securely. We advise owners of this chair to check periodically to make sure the folded/stitched, looped end is lying flat and won't slip through the slot, releasing the belt.

summary: This Safety 1st high chair has adjustable seat height and seat back, but lacks a 5-point harness.

bottomLine: This space-saving, easily portable high chair will surprise you; it did us. Its unique design features take some time to get used to, but it grows on you. The tray table, which swivels down to facilitate getting the child in or out of the chair, or upward for an even more-compact fold, actually serves as part of the restraint system. The chair has no maximum weight capacity listed; it's intended for ages 6 months to about 3 years. Baby Bjorn's website says, "There is no upper weight limit for our high chair. As long as the child fits in the chair, the chair can take the child’s weight." Although it looked snug, we were able to seat a mannequin representing a 3-year-old child (30 lbs, 38 inches tall)
highs: This very small, lightweight chair will surprise you. Takes up remarkably little floor space, and folds up even smaller. There's a steep learning curve with this chair, but once you get used to it, it's easy to use. Very unique design uses tray as part of the restraining system; there is also a 3-point harness. Double tray top means you can take away the dirty one to wash it, and your child will still have a completely clean tray in front of him.
lows: There's a definite learning curve for using the chair. Some features are tricky - almost counterintuitive - to use. The tray is only minimally adjustable horizontally for different age/size children. The manual is a peeve for us; it does not address how to open the folded chair, and several users had difficulty. Most looked for a latch release, and not finding it, tried to pull the legs apart, without success. We worried that just yanking the chair legs apart might damage or break the fold lock, but that is in fact how it is supposed to be done. We found it necessary to pick the folded chair up to do this. It's light, so it wasn't a big deal, but it was annoying.
name: highChair_222269

ratings.description: Ease of use is based on trained panelists' assessments of harness adjustment and use, folding and unfolding, removing and replacing the tray and tray insert (if any), adjusting seat back and height where applicable, removing and replacing the seat cover.
Overall score is based primarily on safety and ease of use.

Safety for each high chair was assessed by our testing, which is based on the voluntary safety standard, ASTM F404-10.  Tests include evaluations of the restraint system, stability of the high chair, and static and dynamic load assessments as well as other tests.

review: Normally, a chair with only a 3-point harness would get a safety score deduction. But this chair, where the tray is intended to serve as crotch post and secondary (to the 3-point harness) restraint, really gets the job done. The spacing between the tray (which is only minimally adjustable horizontally) and the child is tight enough that it would be highly unlikely that a child could climb out.

bottomLine: A Recommended model. For those who want just the basics in a lightweight chair.
highs: Light in weight. Seat cushion is a soft plastic-y foam that is also easily removable, so it's even easier to clean.
lows: Chair does not fold. Light, but has no wheels, so it must be lifted and carried from one spot to another. Tray has what looks like an insert, but it is not removable, and may collect food in that seam. Tray is not adjustable horizontally, either. Backrest is not adjustable.

summary: This is a no-frills, very basic chair. It does not fold. Few adjustable features.

bottomLine: This Bloom high chair was very good in overall performance. It may appeal to parents seeking a spare, modern style. More thought seems to have been given to style than to making it easy to use. There is a learning curve, particularly for the folding process and use of the tray. Neither the seat height nor the seat back is adjustable. Weight:16lb. Size: Medium; projected footprint is 713 square inches.
highs: Harness straps are very easy to adjust to fit child (especially if you remove the padded covers on the straps).
lows: Folding process has huge learning curve, not helped by unclear instructions (e.g., the "trigger" needs to be not just pulled, as the instructions indicated, but pushed and folded under). Seat height is not adjustable. Attachment and removal of tray is somewhat difficult, and not intuitive. Lacks a tray insert. Padded covers on the straps can get in the way of operating the buckle and/or adjusting the straps. Seat cover is difficult to remove and replace. Seat cover is hand-wash (or wipe-clean) only, not machine washable.

summary: This Chicco chair has multiple seat height, tray and seat back positions.

bottomLine: Judged a Don't Buy: Safety Risk due to the the lack of a passive crotch restraint. An unharnessed child could slide beneath the tray and fall to the floor. In a less likely but even worse case, the unharnessed child's legs and torso might fit under the tray, but his head could get caught up on it, and he could strangle. Always, always make sure that your child's harness is fastened when placing him into a high chair, stroller, or other such product.

highs: Very easy to fold. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Has a fixed snack tray as well as an adjustable main tray and tray insert. Tray is very easy to attach and adjust. lows: Has wheels in rear only, making moving the chair more difficult. Tray has a lot of grooves that the tray insert doesn't cover, which can make it easier for food to collect there. Seat cover is wipe-clean only (not machine washable).

bottomLine: This pricey, retro-mod pedestal-style Boon high chair was very good in overall performance. May be chosen for its style rather than its function. Tray operation is not intuitive but can be done one-handed once learned. Seat height is adjustable with no pre-set positions. Seatback does not adjust. Weight: 29lb. Size: Small; projected footprint is 564 square inches.
highs: Relatively compact in terms of floor space. Tray has a learning curve, but once learned can be done one-handed. Seat height has no pre-set positions, adding versatility. Buttons on buckle make it extremely easy to adjust straps. Molded plastic seat and smooth surfaces judged very easy to keep clean. Seat cover is easy to remove and put back on.
lows: Chair is heavy and does not fold. Tray and insert are small. Seat height adjustment is more difficult to use than most; requires more force to pull up or push down than others tested. Seat cover is wipe-clean only.

summary: This pricey Boon high chair resembles a small-scale barber's swivel chair. It has some good features but is heavy and doesn't fold.

bottomLine: Judged a Don't Buy: Safety Risk due to the fact that in our tests, the passive crotch restraint or crotch post, allowed a metal wedge sized to approximate a small child's torso to pass through both of the high chair's leg openings.  An unharnessed child could slide downward and fall to the floor, or strangle if its head got caught on the way down.  Always fasten your child's harness when putting him into a high chair.

An unharnessed child could slide downward and fall to the floor or strangle if its head got caught on the way down.

bottomLine: This compact, bare-bones Cosco high chair was good in overall performance, but not as sturdy as others: one sample's buckle was damaged in testing. lows: Seat cover is wipe-clean only (not machine washable.) Seat height and seat back are not adjustable. Lacks a tray insert.

summary: This wood chair from Eddie Bauer is a classic style, but has only a 3-point harness.

bottomLine: The overall concept of this chair seems better than the execution. The harness, buckle and seat cushion are the best features; the others leave a lot to be desired. Pinching/scissoring hazards when folding and adjusting backrest. Our samples had some rough and/or sharp edges.
highs: Easy to fold and unfold, but we found a pinching hazard in the process (see "Lows"). The top portion of the seat cover is easy to remove & replace.
lows: Folding mechanism involves sliding sleeves on either side of the chair along metal tubes; there's a pinching hazard. (Instructions do warn you.) There is another pinch hazard when adjusting the backrest. The chair is big, with a wide footprint. Tray insert doesn't cover the whole top. Adjusting tray requires paying attention to be sure you're getting in the corresponding slots on either side. Similar issue with adjusting the seat height. if you don't pay attention, seat can be left lopsided. Tray does not feel securely attached, even when you can see that it is in place.

The faux-leather seat cover, which is easy to remove and put back on, and the double, smooth surfaced trays should be easy to keep clean. The Stop & Go system prevents siblings or the child himself from moving the chair when you don't want it moving.

summary: This $300 chair has many good features, including seat recline, seat height adjustment, a double tray with several adjustment positions. It also has a unique "stop & go" brake/wheel lock system; the chair can only be moved while the "stop & go" buttons are depressed. This prevents a sibling from taking the baby for a joy ride.

bottomLine: This Safety 1st high chair was excellent in overall performance. Seat height is adjustable with 7 numbered positions. Seat back adjusts to 3 positions. Weight: 20lb. Size: Large; projected footprint is 791 square inches.
highs: Very easy to fold. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Chair has a snack tray as well as an adjustable main tray and tray insert. Seat cover is machine washable, and is easy to remove and put back on.
lows: While we like that this model has a 5-point harness (unlike most of its brandmates), this chair has a separate chest buckle, adding another step to getting your child strapped in. Harness straps must be fed through buckles to adjust length. Relatively large chair; takes up more floor space than most that we tested.

summary: This Safety 1st high chair has an adjustable seat height and seat back.

bottomLine: Fair in safety due to the fabric crotch restraint, which can pose a fall risk to an unharnessed child. The space between the underside of the tray and the top of the fabric piece is larger than it should be, possibly allowing room for a child to get an arm stuck, or, worse, his legs up and over the restraint. If that child is not harnessed, he could slide under the tray and onto the floor. A second point: the center portion is so wide that babies' inner thighs may become irritated from rubbing against it.
highs: Easy and compact folding.
lows: The passive crotch restraint, rather than being the usual post attached to the front of the seat or the bottom of the tray, is here made of fabric. Rather than being T-shaped, it is like a fat "Y" with the top filled in. It is fastened to the seat on both sides and at the bottom of the "Y". Unfortunately there is more space than there should be between the tray bottom and the top of the restraint fabric, enough for a probe representing a small child's leg to fit through that space. The overly-wide center portion of the crotch restraint could chafe the baby's thighs and cause irritation. There is a scissoring/shearing hazard when the chair is being folded or unfolded. The harness buckle is not easy to operate. Seat cover is hard to remove and replace.
name: astro_222278

ratings.description: Ease of use is based on trained panelists' assessments of harness adjustment and use, folding and unfolding, removing and replacing the tray and tray insert (if any), adjusting seat back and height where applicable, removing and replacing the seat cover.

review:
Folding is smooth and easy. Easy to move along floor. Tray is easy to operate. Harness fairly easy to adjust. Buckle is somewhat difficult to open and close.

The passive crotch restraint, here made of fabric rather than a fixed post, is positioned such that there is too much space between it and the underside of the tray. A child could get a hand or arm stuck in that space, or, worst case, could maneuver his leg(s) on top of the fabric. If unharnessed, he could fall out of the chair.

summary: A few good features (the compactness of its fold for one) but serious safety concerns: the crotch restraint, which on this chair is not a post, but a fabric piece that may not be adequate to keep an unharnessed child in the chair safely, and a scissoring hazard to fingers when the chair is being folded.

bottomLine: This sleek-looking Inglesina high chair was very good in overall performance. Folding has a learning curve, but diagram on frame helps a lot. Once learned, folding is very easy. Separate latches for attaching tray and adjusting its horizontal position are unusual and may be confusing at first. Seat height is adjustable with infinite positions (meaning that there are no set adjustment points or notches). Seatback adjusts to 3 positions. Weight: 26lb. Size: Medium; projected footprint is 662 square inches.
highs: Very easy to fold once learned. Front of chair has a nice amount of clearance, so parent can get close to seated child. Seat cover easy to remove and put back on. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Harness straps are very easy to adjust to fit child.
lows: Buckle judged more difficult to operate than others. Tray has only one horizontal adjustment position; depending on the size of the child, there may be too much or too little space between child's tummy and the tray. Tray insert is very easy for child to pick up and possibly fling. Seat cover is wipe-clean only (not machine washable).

summary: This sleek Inglesina high chair has some good features, and some that are not so good.

bottomLine: This Recommended Peg Perego high chair is a standout in this group. Excellent in overall performance, with many very good features and well-thought-out design. Labels and numbered buttons help enormously with folding, adjusting height, and more, because instruction manual is poor (mostly illustrations and little text). One of the easiest to use. Seat height is adjustable with 7 positions. Seatback adjusts to 4 positions. Weight: 24lb. Size: Medium; projected footprint is 649 square inches.
highs: Very easy to fold and unfold. Two options for tray when folding the chair: can leave tray on and flip it upward, or remove and store on back of chair. Tray is very easy to attach and adjust. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Straps of harness are very easy to adjust to fit child. Seat cover easy to remove (although there are multiple steps to doing it), and easy to put back on. Judged easy to keep clean.
lows: Seat cover is wipe-clean only (not machine washable). Backrest adjustment on one sample was stiff and somewhat hard to squeeze.

bottomLine: This Carter's high chair was excellent overall, but a few of its features were less than well-executed. Folding mechanism was somewhat stiff, less fluid than others. Seat height is adjustable with 5 positions. Seatback adjusts to 4 positions. Weight: 18lb. Size: Medium; projected footprint is 620 square inches.
highs: Seat cover is machine washable. Tray is very easy to attach and adjust. Very easy to fold. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Waist straps of harness are very easy to adjust, but a warning label sewn onto one shoulder strap made that strap harder to adjust.
lows: Has wheels in front only, so, to move the chair, the back must essentially be dragged along. Seat cover is difficult to remove and replace, partly due to extreme difficulty of feeding shoulder straps back through slots in seat back.

summary: Large but functional, with all the bells and whistles, some of which are easier to use than others. In looks and performance it is very similar to the previously tested Maxi-Cosi Piazzo.

bottomLine: A low-priced chair, but no bargain. We have safety concerns with the 3-point harness, which does not come attached to the chair, and for which unclear installation directions are given. Paired with the overly large spacing between the tray's inner edge and the seat back, the child might be able to climb up and out of the seat, and fall to the floor.
highs: A basic wooden child's chair, with a plastic tray; the style may appeal to some parents. The function leaves much to be desired, however. Smallish tray should be easy to clean.
lows: The tray, which may or may not be removable (we asked the company several times and still have gotten no definitive answer), it is very difficult to put on and even more so to take off. Once it's on, we think parents would leave it on the chair, making it harder to get the child in and out, and the tray harder to clean, because it can't just be scrubbed and rinsed in the sink. There is a large space between the tray and the child's torso or belly, leaving lots of room for food or drinks to spill onto the child's lap, the chair seat, or the floor. No height adjustment. No backrest adjustment. No seat pad (although one can be purchased separately). Three point harness is not attached to the frame by the manufacturer, and directions for attaching it are not very clear, with illustrations only.
name: blames_222273

ratings.description: Ease of use is based on trained panelists' assessments of harness adjustment and use, folding and unfolding, removing and replacing the tray and tray insert (if any), adjusting seat back and height where applicable, removing and replacing the seat cover.
Overall score is based primarily on safety and ease of use.

Safety for each high chair was assessed by our testing, which is based on the voluntary safety standard, ASTM F404-10.  Tests include evaluations of the restraint system, stability of the high chair, and static and dynamic load assessments as well as other tests.

review: The 3-point harness does not come attached to the chair by the manufacturer, as it should be. The instructions are really not adequate for installing it correctly. The crotch belt, if not installed with the buckle beneath the seat, can pull right out of the chair's slot. The chair also fails an aspect of the Passive Containment requirement, in that the distance from the non-adjustable tray to the seat back is too far. That can leave room not only for a mess, with room for food and drink to fall onto the child's lap, but can also give him enough room to pull his legs up and try to get out of the chair. The 3-point harness will not restrain his upper body. The child could tip the chair over, or fall while trying to climb out.

summary: This is not so much a high chair, as it is a bare bones, non-folding wooden chair with a plastic tray. We have safety concerns about the 3-point harness, which must be attached to the chair by the consumer.

bottomLine: This Fisher-Price high chair is a CR Best Buy. It was excellent in overall performance, and was very easy to use. Seat height is adjustable with 4 positions. Seat back adjusts to 3 positions. Weight: 18lb. Size: Small; projected footprint is 530 square inches.
highs: Relatively compact. Flip design gives more clearance at sides and back. Tray is very easy to attach and adjust. Multiple seat-height settings add versatility. Harness adjustment system is excellent, making it very easy to adjust straps to fit child. The chair as a whole is judged easy to keep clean. The seat cover is machine washable, and easy to remove and put back on.
lows: In process of folding, buttons are pressed in sequence, but occasionally the first would pop back up, relatching itself, before the second could be pressed. There is a learning curve to the process. Tray must be removed to fold chair, but unlike some other models, there's no place to store it on the chair frame.

summary: We have designated the BeBeLove 604-1 a Don't Buy: Safety Risk due to the lack of a passive crotch restraint (also referred to as a crotch post). An unharnessed child could slide downward and fall to the floor, or strangle if its head gets caught on the way down.

bottomLine: A Recommended model. If you want a wooden high chair that your child can use beyond his high chair stage, this is it. It's easy to use, and most importantly, safe. Adjusting the high chair seat is very easy, and (unlike other wooden models) the Sprout doesn't require you to keep an allen wrench handy. Same for footrest; no wrench required. Tray is easy to attach and adjust. Judged easier to clean. A good, basic highchair that can grow with your child.
highs: Takes up less floor space than many high chairs. Adjusting the high chair seat is easy, and (unlike other wooden models) doesn't require you to keep an allen wrench handy. Same for footrest; no wrench required. Tray is easy to attach and adjust, and easy to clean. Harness is easy to adjust. Buckle is easy to operate. Seat cover is easy to remove and replace.
lows: Does not fold. Heavy. Backrest is not adjustable. No tray insert.

summary: One of Dorel Juvenile Groups many toddler booster seats offered under the Safety 1st name. Similar to the Safety 1st Rumi.

bottomLine: A good performer if it suits your vehicle. Not a seat we recommend for older vehicles that have only lap belts and no top-tether anchor. Britax recommends the tether be used at all times. Although this seat has a good fit-to-vehicle score, achieving that fit can be difficult due to complicated belt routing and multiple belt routing options. LATCH installation is better, but the seat can't be used to the full 85lbs harness capacity if installed with LATCH. The large side impact cushions add some width to this seat. If you need to install other child seats next to this seat be sure to check that they will fit next to each other.
highs:
• Push-on LATCH connectors
  • High harness (85 lbs.) and booster (120 lbs.) capacity can keep children harnessed longer and offer a good option for heavier kids
  • Head restraint offers added adjustment for taller kids when the seat is used in booster mode
lows:
• High price. Multiple belt routing options referred to as the "Short belt path" and "Long belt path" complicate installation
  • The long belt path is difficult to use but may be needed to get a secure installation in some cars
  • The short belt path, although easier, may not provide a secure installation
  • Not a good choice for older cars that have lap belts only and no top tether
  • When used as a booster, the wide belt guides may not position the shoulder belt in an optimal position

summary: The Frontier 85 SICT is one of many toddler booster seats offered by Britax. This seat is based on the Frontier 85 is similar but includes an additional side impact-protection feature.

bottomLine: Though not laden with features, the Ventura is a reasonably priced straightforward seat that works well in both harnessed and booster modes. What this seat lacks in features it makes up for in its simple design and straight forward use.
highs:
• Good crash protection scores whether used with the harness or as a booster.
  • Lighter weight makes this seat easier to transport.
  • Reasonable price.
  • Very good crash protection / belt fit in booster mode.
lows: • Continuous harness loop makes it harder to maintain even tension for the harness on both sides.

summary: The Safety 1st Ventura is a toddler booster seat offered by Dorel Juvenile Group under the Safety 1st Brand. It is similar in design and function to the Cosco Highback.

bottomLine: A reasonably priced seat that performs well if you can get a secure installation. We found the best way to achieve a secure fit was to fold back the cover of the seat to access the belt path behind where your child will sit. Pulling the belt from this location gives you a better angle to tighten the belt and makes the seat easier to secure. When switching to booster mode be sure to pay close attention to see if the belt fits your child correctly. We found this seat only did a fair job of positioning the vehicle seat belt on a child sized dummy in our tests.
highs:
• Lighter weight seat makes it easier to transport
  • Reasonable price
lows:
• Difficult to get secure with seatbelt installation in some cars that have belts mounted forward of the seatback
  • Narrow belt path
  • Harness adjusts without rethreading but requires uninstalling the seat to change harness position
  • May require pulling LATCH strap into belt path to secure

bottomLine: A narrow, lightweight seat that may accommodate older booster-aged kids best.
highs: Narrow seat fits contoured or narrow vehicle seats better. Lightweight.
lows: Lacks the lateral protection, improved belt placement, and more comfortable place for a child to rest his head that the side wings and belt guides of a highback booster provide. Lap belt must be 'threaded' into slot between the armrests with each use. Longer cushion may not fit smaller booster-aged kids' legs well, causing them to slouch--a safety concern.

bottomLine: A booster seat that can accommodate larger and heavier kids longer.
highs: A minimum weight limit of 40 lbs. (for both low- and highback use) encourages parents not to transition children from a harnessed seat to a booster too early. Heavier upper-weight limit of 120 lbs. can allow heavier children to use this booster--a safety plus.
lows: Some slack can build in lap portion of belt due to increased friction through SlideGuard clip, when child moves. SlideGuard length is awkward to adjust and located on underside of booster.

bottomLine: Like the Evenflo Symphony 65 on which its based, one of the best overall performers among all-in-one models. Best suited to forward-facing and booster use. We would forgo the Snugli with its premium price and and instead purchase the lower priced and similar performing Evenflo Symphony.

  • Provides very good belt placement in booster mode
lows:
• Premium price
  • SureLATCH orientation must be adjusted to allow use in some vehicles
  • Difficult or impossible to replace cover after installing rear-facing with a seatbelt

summary: The only all-in-one model offered by Snugli. This model is a premium version of the Symphony 65 e3 sold under the Snugli name. The fabrics on the Snugli line are marketed as a temperature-regulating fabric that helps keep your child comfortable.

bottomLine: This seat is large and heavy, but has benefits for larger kids (both rear and forward facing), for cars that don't have lap and shoulder (3-point) belts or top tethers, and for travel. But it suits these special cases better than it does everyday use. It is often used when parents need three car seats to fit across a vehicle rear seat, due to its narrow shape. Provides good belt fit in booster mode.
highs:
• Harness capacity up to 40 lbs. rear facing, 65 lb. forward-facing and 100 lbs. in booster mode make this a seat that can accomodate larger kids
  • A good alternative to a booster seat for vehicles equipped with only lap belts
  • Narrow width may allow three car seats to fit across in some vehicle back seats
  • Designed to fold for travel.
lows:
• Price
  • Heavy and long seat
  • Very difficult to securely install rear-facing and lacks recline indicator
  • Requires separate rear-facing platform (included) to be attached to the seat to achieve correct recline

summary: Diono is the new name for what was previously Sunshine Kids child seats that now incorporate a booster mode making them all-in-one seats.

bottomLine: This seat is large and heavy, but has benefits for larger kids (both rear and forward facing), for cars that don't have lap and shoulder (3-point) belts or top tethers, and for travel. But it suits these special cases better than it does everyday use. When used in booster mode, the fact that this seat's shoulder belt guide allows the shoulder belt to lay slack when a child moves also makes it a poor choice for use in booster mode. It is often used when parents need three car seats to fit across a vehicle rear seat, due to its narrow width.
highs:
• Harness capacity up to 45 lbs. rear facing, 80 lb. forward-facing and 120 lbs. in booster mode make this a seat that can accomodate larger kids
  • A good alternative to a booster seat for vehicles equipped with only lap belts
  • Narrow width may allow three car seats to fit across in some vehicle back seats
  • Designed to fold for travel.
lows:
• Price.
  • Heavy and long seat
  • Very difficult to securely install rear-facing and lacks recline indicator
  • Long back may not fit in smaller vehicles well
  • Requires separate rear-facing platform (included) to be attached to the seat to achieve correct recline
  • The shoulder belt guide used in booster mode is awkward to use and causes the belt to fold and bind within it causing the should belt to lay slack, a safety concern

specs.description: A five-point harness secures the child's upper body and torso for better safety, in our opinion.  "Five-point" refers to the 2 shoulder straps, a waist strap secured to the seat back on either side of the child's midsection, and a crotch strap.  A three-point harness lacks shoulder straps and secures just the waist and lower torso.
The stroller's handle can be adjusted for height or angle to better suit parents of differing heights.

A stroller that is car-seat compatible lets you mount a car seat directly onto the stroller, and comes with any other items, such as an adaptor bar, that are needed to properly install the car seat.  (If you must buy the adaptor separately, we do not consider that stroller "car-seat compatible" as sold.)
One-touch brakes work quickly for added safety. They're also more convenient than standard brakes.  A few models now have hand-operated parking brakes, arguably even more convenient.
This is convenient in restaurants or other tight spaces. It also makes storing at home easier.

Suitability for babies 6 months and younger means the stroller could include a safety flap at the child's feet so he or she doesn't slip out of a large leg hole, or some other means of containing a child of this age. Even with this added feature, the harness should still be used.
Five-point harness secures child firmly. Unlike a three-point harness, it secures the upper body.
An adjustable handle can accommodate parents of different heights.

To avoid risk of injury. Babies have been injured and strangled by baby monitor cords placed too close to the crib where the child was able to reach them.  If using a baby unit with a cord, be sure to keep it well out of arm's reach of the baby.
Frequency band is the wavelength at which the unit operates.
This is a light or beep that is a definite indicator that the parent and baby unit are 'linked' or 'not linked' i.e. communicating.
This is a light (or an icon on an LCD display) that lets you know the batteries in your parent unit are running low.
Some models feature lullabies and/or other soothing music that will play for your baby at the push of a button.
Some models have a simple nightlight on the baby's unit.
This is a light or beep that lets you know definitively that you've reached the range limit of the monitor, and won't be able to hear if your child cries.
Rechargeable batteries may save parents money over time, especially those who rely on batteries more than AC power for the receiver(s).

Lights on the monitor turn on when the baby cries; the louder he cries, the more lights light up.  This lets you turn the volume down and still know when the baby is crying, or, if you are in a very noisy room, you'll see the lights and know when baby is awake or crying.

specs.displayName: Talk to baby from parent unit
specs.description: This feature allows the parent to push a button and talk to the baby, alerting him/her that mom or dad is on the way.
Displays the temperature in the baby's room.
